timeline.message:
make security states configurable

Signed-off-by: Eugen Freiter <freiter@gmx.de>

timeline.bodyHTML:
Suggested change
private final Map<CurrentSecuritySystemStateEnum, String> currentStateMapping = new EnumMap(
private final Map<CurrentSecuritySystemStateEnum, String> currentStateMapping = new EnumMap<>(
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
i get
'<>' cannot be used with anonymous classes
should keep it as it is or change to
 private final Map<TargetSecuritySystemStateEnum, String> targetStateMapping = new EnumMap<TargetSecuritySystemStateEnum, String>(
?
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText:
Honestly, creating an anonymous subclass of EnumMap for the sole purpose of populating initial values is something I frown upon because it mixes up class implementation with class usage which should generally be two separate concerns when coding. The error you are seeing is one such side-effect of that mixing up.
But in order to not force even more changes right now I suggest to just change it to private final Map<TargetSecuritySystemStateEnum, String> targetStateMapping = new EnumMap<TargetSecuritySystemStateEnum, String>(
replies.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
i will change as you suggested.
but how you would do it without anonymous subclass? with a dedicate classes, e.g. SecurityCurrentStateMapping? or something else? originally i was thinking about kind of xml based configuration, it was too complex and too error-prone at the end.
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText: You would typically populate the map in the HomeSecuritySystemImpl constructor, or you could (although I don't really recommend it either since it is kinda unorthodox) just put the population logic in a raw statement block {...} right below your field declaration. It is like static initialization but you just remove the static keyword.
replies.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: ok.  understood. i will keep it as it is for now. we consider to change it all places at once to constructor based init in a later PR
replies.author: yfre
